questions.text: A 69-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a total pancreatectomy in one month. He has a history of chronic pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and severe osteoarthritis in both knees. He is unable to climb the stairs because of knee pain and only walks indoors around his house. He has severe abdominal pain due to chronic pancreatitis but does not report any chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes and consumed 4–6 beers daily for 25 years but quit smoking and alcohol consumption 5 years ago. Current medications include insulin, metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin, ibuprofen, and pregabalin. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and a 12-lead ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for assessing this patient's perioperative cardiac risk?

choices.text: Serial troponin and natriuretic peptide measurement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ambulatory ECG monitoring is indicated when standard ECG fails to provide information about symptoms such as palpitations or unexplained syncope, but it is not used to assess preoperative cardiac risk. Additionally, this patient has no history of rhythm or conduction abnormalities.

B) CORRECT:

The goal of preoperative cardiac stress testing (CST) is to identify patients who might require cardiac revascularization before nonemergent surgeries. Preoperative CST should be considered for a patient who has a high major adverse cardiac event risk and poor or unknown functional capacity. CST is performed using ECG or cardiac imaging (e.g., stress echocardiography, myocardial perfusion imaging). An exercise stress test can be performed if the patient is able to achieve ≥ 5 metabolic equivalents using the chosen exercise modality. For patients who are unable to do so, pharmacological stress testing (i.e., with adenosine, dipyridamole, regadenoson, or dobutamine) is the most appropriate option. If a stress test is abnormal, preoperative revascularization (percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting) can be considered to decrease the risk of major adverse cardiac events.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonstress echocardiography is not routinely indicated for the preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing noncardiac surgery, but it may be performed if there are specific indications for the test, such as heart failure, new onset (or exacerbation) of cardiac symptoms, or known valvular heart disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is performed in patients who are symptomatic (with angina or angina equivalents) and have an intermediate to high pretest probability of coronary artery disease (CAD). Coronary angiography, regardless of whether performed noninvasively (with a CT scan) or invasively (using cardiac catheterization), should not be performed as the first step to assess perioperative cardiac risk in asymptomatic patients without known CAD.

E) INCORRECT:

Serial troponin measurement is important when a patient is suspected to have an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) but plays no role in preoperative risk assessment for asymptomatic patients without evidence of ACS. While natriuretic peptide B is a biomarker that is increasingly being used to assess perioperative risk, its measurement is typically for patients known to have cardiovascular disease or suspected to have heart failure.
questions.hint: The combination of high-risk surgery (major intraabdominal surgery) and multiple cardiovascular risk factors (insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia) indicates a high risk of myocardial infarction in the intra- and postoperative periods.

A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a preoperative visit. He has a scheduled tumor resection for adenocarcinoma of the colon in 1 week. He was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma in the colon during a recent hospitalization. Staging showed that the tumor had infiltrated into the visceral peritoneum and that there was no distant metastasis. He has had a decreased appetite and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. He used to play tennis but stopped 3 months ago as he was having trouble keeping pace with the game. He has stable angina, mild intermittent asthma, and hypertension. He quit smoking last year but used to smoke 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and an albuterol inhaler, which he last used 3 months ago. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 56.7 kg (125 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min and regular, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hair thinning and loss of the subcutaneous fat in his cheeks. The thyroid gland is enlarged. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in preoperative management?

choices.text: Measurement of free T4 and total T3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is routinely used in the preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing thoracic surgery or to help plan lung resection. It is also used to preoperatively evaluate patients undergoing nonthoracic procedures who have unexplained dyspnea, exercise intolerance, or lung disease (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma) with significantly impaired airflow or abnormal baseline level of respiratory function. This patient will undergo intraabdominal rather than thoracic surgery. Additionally, as he last used his rescue inhaler 3 months ago and his lung examination was normal, his asthma is controlled and he has no evidence of significantly impaired airflow, making PFT unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Antianginal drugs such as metoprolol and other beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and nitrates can have deleterious effects if stopped abruptly, including exacerbation of ischemic heart disease with worsened angina and even myocardial infarction. Patients on metoprolol should continue to take the agent in the perioperative period, either enterally or parenterally. On the day of the procedure, metoprolol and any other necessary medications can be safely taken with sips of water 2 hours prior to anesthesia.

C) INCORRECT:

24-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring can be useful in detecting transient ECG changes, such as those associated with episodes of palpitations. A preoperative ECG is recommended in patients with one or more of the Revised Cardiac Risk Indicators as well as one of the following risk factors: age > 65 years, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, peripheral vascular disease, or arrhythmias. Although a preoperative ECG is indicated in this patient, a single ECG is generally sufficient for preoperative assessments.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has malnutrition, as indicated by low albumin and protein levels, a recent weight loss of > 7.5% body weight in 3 months, loss of subcutaneous fat, muscle wasting, enlargement of the thyroid gland (likely due to iodine deficiency), and reduced functional capacity. Because of the potential negative outcomes associated with malnutrition, all preoperative patients should be screened for appropriate nutritional status. Malnourished patients should receive nutritional support, which may be delivered either enterally or parenterally. Enteral feeding helps preserve the normal physiology and immune function of the digestive system and therefore should be preferred over parenteral nutritional support whenever possible. Oral feeding is not contraindicated in this patient so he would benefit from high-protein oral nutritional supplementation, which is recommended for malnourished patients with malignancy or wounds.

Other preoperative testing this patient may need includes a chest x-ray, since he is > 60 years of age, has a history of cardiac disease, and a recent history of significant cigarette use, as well as an ECG, because he is > 65 years old and has a history of ischemic heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring free T4 and total T3 could help determine the functionality of the thyroid gland. Hyperthyroidism can also manifest with thyromegaly and weight loss. However, this patient's low albumin and protein suggest a different underlying cause of his weight loss. In addition, this patient does not have other symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as tachycardia, heat intolerance, diarrhea, or increased appetite. Lastly, if there was a concern for hyperthyroidism, the first-line test to evaluate thyroid function would be measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone, not free T4 and total T3.

F) INCORRECT:

Selective bowel decontamination is primarily used prior to liver transplant surgery, but can also be useful in decreasing the incidence of nosocomial pneumonia and mortality in intubated patients. Bowel decontamination is not a common practice for cases of colon resection. In addition, vancomycin is not a first-choice antibiotic for selective bowel decontamination as it is mainly used for gram-positive coverage or when MRSA is suspected. It is not used against gram-negative rods, which are common organisms in the GI tract.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient has multiple risk factors for postoperative complications, e.g., age > 60 years, a history of cardiac disease with significant smoking history, abnormal laboratory findings and exam findings (e.g., enlarged thyroid, loss of subcutaneous fat), and cancer. He needs appropriate preoperative evaluation and optimization prior to undergoing surgery.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is associated with poorer postoperative outcomes including increased overall morbidity and mortality, longer hospital stays, increased risk of infection, delayed wound healing, and increased rate of ICU admissions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preoperative evaluation prior to an elective laparoscopic umbilical hernia repair. She feels well, but reports shortness of breath on mild exertion. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and underwent placement of a stent in her left anterior descending artery. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (176.4 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pulmonary examination shows scattered crackles bilaterally. There is jugular venous distension. Abdominal examination shows a large umbilical hernia; cough impulse is present. ECG shows sinus rhythm and 2 to 3 premature atrial contractions per minute. Chest x-ray shows widened intercostal spaces and mild cardiomegaly. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although metabolic syndrome, which this patient most likely has (indicated by the patient's diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and obesity), increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, it is not an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications according to the revised cardiac risk index. Diabetes mellitus alone is considered a risk factor but only if the patient already requires treatment with insulin, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient's age is important to consider when planning surgery because old age is associated with an increased prevalence of conditions that increase the risk of perioperative cardiac complications (e.g., cardiovascular disease, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes mellitus). According to the Goldman risk index, patients ≥ 70 years of age are considered to be at increased risk of cardiac complications; this patient is 62 years of age. Furthermore, according to the revised cardiac risk index (the index most commonly used for perioperative cardiac risk assessment), age alone is not considered an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications.

C) CORRECT:

Jugular venous distention is a manifestation of this patient's CHF and a significant preoperative risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications. This patient's CHF and ischemic heart disease meet two of the criteria of the revised cardiac risk index (RCRI), putting her at increased risk of a perioperative cardiac event (e.g., acute myocardial infarction, cardiac arrest). Before undergoing surgery, this patient should be treated for CHF and undergo further cardiologic evaluation with a cardiac stress test.

The Goldman risk index, developed in 1977, is no longer the preferred tool for assessing cardiac risk. It includes the presence of heart failure signs (JVD, S3 gallop) as the strongest risk factor for cardiac complications. RCRI (the updated version of the Goldman risk index) is now the most commonly used tool to assess perioperative cardiac risk.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of smoking increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Therefore, smoking cessation 8 weeks prior to surgery should be encouraged and perioperative pulmonary assessment should be considered. However, smoking is not an independent risk factor for perioperative cardiac complications according to the revised cardiac risk index.

E) INCORRECT:

Although premature atrial contractions (PACs) can indicate an underlying heart disease they are also commonly found in healthy individuals without heart disease. Therefore, the Goldman risk index includes all arrhythmias as risk factors for perioperative cardiac complications except for premature atrial contractions. In the revised cardiac risk index (the index most commonly used for perioperative cardiac risk assessment), arrhythmias are no longer considered independent risk factors for perioperative cardiac complications.
questions.hint: This patient's shortness of breath on mild exertion, crackles on auscultation, and cardiomegaly on chest x-ray, in combination with a history of ischemic heart disease, suggest congestive heart failure (CHF).

An abdominal ultrasound shows a nodular liver surface, free intraperitoneal fluid, and multiple small stones in the gallbladder. There is fluid in the gallbladder wall with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid and stranding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral rifaximin and lactulose are both first-line treatments for hepatic encephalopathy, for which this patient is at risk given her cirrhosis. Because this patient's mental status appears normal, she is not encephalopathic.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is indicated to correct elevated PT/INR in non-emergencies. While this patient may benefit from correction of her borderline-elevated INR, vitamin K supplementation is ineffective in patients with cirrhosis. Vitamin K is simply a substrate used by the liver to make clotting factors. However, if the liver's synthetic function is compromised (as in cirrhotics), then vitamin K supplementation will not have any significant effect on coagulation. In coagulopathic patients with cirrhosis, clotting factors themselves (e.g., FFP) must be provided.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with ascites, abdominal paracentesis is both diagnostic and therapeutic. Patients with cirrhosis are at much higher risk of perioperative morbidity and mortality, especially if complications of liver dysfunction are present (e.g., ascites, coagulopathy, encephalopathy). Perioperative mortality increases with Child-Pugh score (grade A-10%, B-30%, C-80%). In all but the most urgent surgeries, patients with cirrhosis should have such complications corrected before proceeding to surgery in order to minimize the risk of surgical morbidity. In this case, abdominal paracentesis would allow for laboratory analysis of the ascitic fluid. Additionally, it would also help relieve the high intraabdominal pressure associated with ascites, thus, decreasing the risk of surgical wound dehiscence.

This patient may also receive fresh frozen plasma given her borderline coagulation studies and IV antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole) for her cholecystitis. Once ascites and coagulation are normalized, she should undergo cholecystectomy.

D) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the standard treatment option for cholecystitis in good operative candidates. While this patient has cholecystitis, she also has evidence of liver disease which significantly increases her perioperative risk. Other interventions are indicated before it is safe to proceed with cholecystectomy.

E) INCORRECT:

Open cholecystectomy is indicated for patients with cholecystitis if laparoscopic approach fails or if complications are suspected (e.g., gangrene or perforation). While this patient has cholecystitis, it is most likely uncomplicated so open surgery is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute cholecystitis (acute RUQ pain, fever, positive Murphy sign, and signs of gallbladder inflammation on ultrasound). In addition, high-risk alcohol use and findings of a nodular liver surface, hepatomegaly, telangiectasias, and ascites (shifting dullness, free intraperitoneal fluid) suggest cirrhosis and hepatic dysfunction, which should be considered for clinical decision-making.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of worsening right hip pain that radiates to his groin. Over-the-counter analgesics have not alleviated the pain. His medical history is remarkable for hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder. He has not been hospitalized recently. Current medications include losartan and fluoxetine. He has no known allergies. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 133/89 mm Hg. Examination of the right hip shows a limited range of motion and palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicits pain. An x-ray of the right hip shows joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation. The patient is scheduled for an elective total hip replacement. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent surgical site infection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aztreonam primarily covers gram-negative bacilli. Aztreonam does not cover the most common causes of SSI following an elective orthopedic procedure and is therefore not indicated as the first-line antibiotic for SSI prophylaxis in this scenario. Aztreonam is recommended as part of the first-line regimen in urologic procedures that do not enter the urinary tract and involve prosthesis implantation.

B) CORRECT:

Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin and has activity against gram-positive cocci and certain gram-negative pathogens such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and E. coli. A single dose of intravenous cefazolin administered 30–60 minutes before the first surgical incision is an appropriate regimen for perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis in most procedures, including orthopedic surgeries. In the case of beta-lactam allergy, clindamycin or vancomycin can be used. In procedures such as appendectomy, colorectal surgery, and small bowel surgery, intravenous metronidazole should be added to cover anaerobes (e.g., Bacteroides fragilis). For colorectal surgeries, oral antibiotic therapy with neomycin and erythromycin, or with neomycin and metronidazole, should be performed for bowel preparation the day before surgery.

No perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis is needed for low-risk laparoscopic cholecystectomy or for clean surgeries of the hand, foot, knee, or head and neck region if no foreign body is implanted.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, which are typically implicated in SSIs following elective orthopedic procedures. However, for most surgical procedures, including orthopedic procedures, vancomycin is only recommended for patients with beta-lactam allergy (i.e., as a second-line drug for perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis).

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin. It has a broad spectrum of activity, including against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). This antibiotic is reserved for use in severe skin and soft tissue infections. It should not be used for routine perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin primarily covers anaerobic bacteria but also has some activity against gram-positive bacteria, which are typically implicated in SSIs following elective orthopedic procedures. However, for most surgical procedures, including orthopedic procedures, clindamycin is only recommended for patients with beta-lactam allergy (i.e., as a second-line drug for perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis).
questions.hint: The most common pathogens causing surgical site infections (SSIs) after orthopedic surgeries are streptococcal species, Staphylococcus aureus, and coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis).

Urinalysis shows 1+ protein. ECG shows signs of left ventricular hypertrophy, which is unchanged from the previous ECG. Chest x-ray and pulmonary function tests show no abnormalities. Which of the following preoperative recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Perform a transthoracic echocardiography before surgery
Stop metformin on the morning of surgery and initiate insulin therapy
Stop aspirin 10 days before surgery and bridge with enoxaparin
Stop metformin on the morning of surgery, lisinopril one day before, and aspirin one week before surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) may be recommended in patients with suspected heart failure, left ventricular dysfunction, or valvular disease. This patient has good exercise tolerance (walks 4 miles without developing fatigue or dyspnea) and his cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. His left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG is most likely related to his personal history of hypertension and does not warrant a TTE at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing metformin therapy on the morning of surgery and starting insulin therapy should be considered in patients with diabetes and poor glycemic control (HbA1c ≥ 7%). For this patient undergoing spinal surgery, discontinuing metformin is appropriate, but insulin therapy is likely unnecessary because he has good glycemic control (HbA1c 6.1%). However, careful blood glucose monitoring during surgery is important.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy is typically discontinued 7–10 days before surgeries with a high risk of perioperative bleeding (e.g., craniotomy, spinal surgery). Bridging with enoxaparin is indicated in patients who pause warfarin therapy before surgery. Since this patient is not taking warfarin, enoxaparin bridging is not necessary.

D) CORRECT:

Preoperative patient evaluation and management, which includes medication adjustment, play an important role in the prevention of perioperative complications such as hypoglycemia, hypotension, and hemorrhage. Metformin, which increases the risk of renal hypoperfusion and intraoperative lactic acidosis, should be discontinued on the day of surgery. Aspirin is typically discontinued for 7–10 days before procedures with a high bleeding risk (e.g., craniotomy, spinal surgery), but it is continued for most other procedures. Recommendations vary on discontinuing ACE inhibitors (ACEIs) and ARBs. Some guidelines recommend continuing therapy, while recent evidence suggests holding ACEIs 24 hours before surgery unless the patient has a history of heart failure or severe hypertension. Beta blockers such as bisoprolol should be continued. Statin therapy and topical steroid cream may be continued because both carry minimal perioperative risk. Important lifestyle modifications for the prevention of postoperative complications include smoking cessation for at least 8 weeks prior to surgery and complete fasting from at least 2 hours before surgery.

See “Perioperative medication management” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) can be considered as a preoperative measure in patients undergoing lung resection or transplantation to assess functional capacity and predict the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. This patient is undergoing spinal surgery, for which routine preoperative CPET is not indicated. His exercise tolerance (walks 4 miles without developing fatigue or dyspnea) and normal findings on chest x-ray and pulmonary function testing make additional functional testing unnecessary.
questions.hint: This patient's examination findings and diagnostic test results do not raise any preoperative concerns.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents for evaluation of acute knee pain and swelling following a recent total knee replacement. He is confused and cannot give an adequate history of his symptoms.
His wife states that he has a history of hypertension and insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes and that he underwent coronary artery bypass surgery 5 years ago. She notes that he has experienced exertional chest pain once or twice per month for the past 3 months, which was relieved with nitroglycerin.
On examination, he has a temperature of 39.0°C, a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, a regular heart rate of 120 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while he is breathing ambient air. Except for tachycardia, his cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. His right knee is erythematous, warm, swollen, and tender to palpation. His electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and nonspecific ST-T changes.
Arthrocentesis is performed, which confirms acute septic arthritis. The patient is given normal saline and appropriate antibiotics, which improve his heart rate and blood pressure. It is determined that urgent knee surgery is needed.
Which one of the following preoperative cardiac testing and management approaches is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with a beta-blocker and proceed with surgery
Start intravenous nitroglycerin and proceed with surgery
Perform urgent cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither a beta-blocker nor nitroglycerin would be indicated in a critically ill patient who has no clinical or electrocardiographic evidence of active coronary ischemia; the risk of exacerbating hypotension would outweigh any potential benefit.

B) CORRECT:

An acutely ill patient with a history of stable coronary artery disease who requires emergency surgery should proceed directly to surgery without additional preoperative cardiac testing. There is no evidence that delaying surgery in order to perform invasive coronary angiography or coronary CT angiography would generate information that would improve the perioperative outcome.

If this patient had active congestive heart failure, clear evidence of acute myocardial ischemia, or hemodynamically significant arrhythmias, then close collaboration among treating practitioners (which might include the primary care provider, cardiologist, surgeon, and anesthesiologist) would be required to individualize and optimize his cardiovascular status while he was being prepared to go to the operating room.

Key learning point: Patients with stable coronary disease do not require preoperative cardiac testing before noncardiac surgery if the surgical procedure must be performed immediately.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither a beta-blocker nor nitroglycerin would be indicated in a critically ill patient who has no clinical or electrocardiographic evidence of active coronary ischemia; the risk of exacerbating hypotension would outweigh any potential benefit.

D) INCORRECT:

An acutely ill patient with a history of stable coronary artery disease who requires emergency surgery should proceed directly to surgery without additional preoperative cardiac testing. There is no evidence that delaying surgery in order to perform invasive coronary angiography or coronary CT angiography would generate information that would improve the perioperative outcome.

E) INCORRECT:

An acutely ill patient with a history of stable coronary artery disease who requires emergency surgery should proceed directly to surgery without additional preoperative cardiac testing. There is no evidence that delaying surgery in order to perform invasive coronary angiography or coronary CT angiography would generate information that would improve the perioperative outcome.

A 54-year-old man with hypertension, gout, and coronary artery disease presents for a preoperative consultation. She has a history of coronary artery disease, after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery 2 years ago, and has chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator. Proceed to surgery without additional cardiac testing or medications

He has a history of heart failure from an ischemic cardiomyopathy (left ventricular ejection fraction, 40%), coronary artery bypass grafting 20 years ago, hypertension, and insulin-treated type 2 diabetes.
His blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 105 beats per minute. He has jugular venous distention to 10 cm, bibasilar crackles in the lungs, trace lower-extremity edema, and a rigid abdomen that is tender to palpation, with rebound tenderness.
His serum glucose level is 185 mg/dL (reference range, 70–100), and an electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia, left ventricular hypertrophy, and nonspecific T-wave inversions in the inferolateral leads.
A dose of intravenous furosemide is given.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Proceed with surgery after blood glucose is controlled and a statin has been administered
Proceed with surgery immediately after cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography
Treat heart failure symptoms and proceed with surgery when euvolemic
Proceed with surgery after administering an intravenous beta-blocker

A) INCORRECT:

Administering a statin and an agent for glucose control should not delay emergency surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Undergoing cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography would only delay the surgery without influencing outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients requiring nonurgent surgery, acute heart failure exacerbation should be treated until the patient is euvolemic before proceeding with surgery. However, this patient needs to go to the operating room immediately. Short-term treatment with medications such as a loop diuretic may be prudent to stabilize the patient as they prepare for immediate surgery.

D) CORRECT:

Although this patient has multiple cardiac risk factors and symptoms of acute heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, he needs to be taken to surgery without delay. No cardiac testing is required.

Key learning point: The best management for a patient with multiple cardiac risk factors who requires emergency surgery is to proceed with the surgery.

Beta-blocker therapy benefits patients at high risk when initiated at least one week before surgery. However, it is not indicated in a patient with decompensated heart failure.

A 63-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease presents for preoperative evaluation before surgical repair of a torn right rotator cuff.
She develops exertional angina after approximately 30 minutes of brisk walking that resolves with rest; these symptoms have been stable for 2 years. She underwent an exercise single-photon-emission CT nuclear stress test 11 months ago, which revealed a small area of mild reversibility in the inferior wall. At that time, her left ventricular ejection fraction was 61%. She was managed medically, and her symptoms have been stable since. She denies dyspnea, leg swelling, or orthopnea.
Her current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg at bedtime, pantoprazole 40 mg daily, and metoprolol succinate 100 mg daily.
Her blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg, and her heart rhythm is regular at a rate of 66 beats per minute. She has no murmurs or gallops on cardiac examination. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.
In addition to continuing the beta-blocker and statin, which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for this patient's preoperative management?

choices.text: Perform cardiac catheterization and percutaneous coronary intervention for any significant lesions
Perform an exercise treadmill test without imaging
No further evaluation is required; proceed to surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary revascularization should be considered before noncardiac surgery in patients with recent unstable angina or recent myocardial infarction. In addition, cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography should be considered for patients in whom recently progressive symptoms or recent noninvasive testing suggests a high probability of high-risk disease (e.g., significant left main coronary artery stenosis, three-vessel disease, or two-vessel disease with significant proximal left anterior descending artery stenosis); in some of those cases, angiography and possibly revascularization might be indicated independent of the noncardiac surgery. In this patient with long-standing stable angina and good functional status, there is no indication for performing a cardiac catheterization.

B) INCORRECT:

In this patient with long-standing stable angina and good functional status, there is no indication for performing a treadmill test without imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the patient has no symptoms of heart failure and no physical findings consistent with severe valvular disease, an echocardiogram is unlikely to alter clinical management.

D) CORRECT:

Coronary revascularization before noncardiac surgery is not recommended in patients with stable ischemic symptoms and low-risk disease, given that randomized trials have shown no benefit of preoperative revascularization in reducing the risk for adverse cardiac events in these patients.

Key learning point: The most appropriate preoperative management of a patient who has coronary artery disease and stable angina; has adequate blood pressure and heart rate control; takes aspirin, a beta-blocker, and a statin; and is scheduled to undergo intermediate-risk noncardiac surgery is to proceed to surgery without additional evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient with long-standing stable angina and good functional status, there is no indication for repeating a nuclear stress test.

She has a history of insulin-treated type 2 diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and stenting of the left anterior descending coronary artery 5 years ago. She states that she has had no recent chest pain and can walk one block with a cane, limited by right leg claudication. Her current medications are aspirin, rosuvastatin, atenolol, and insulin.
Her heart rate is 58 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 115/85 mm Hg. She has no jugular venous distention, no murmurs, and no lower-extremity edema. Peripheral pulses are barely detectable.
An electrocardiogram is normal.
Which one of the following preoperative management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

The patient does not report heart failure symptoms, so an echocardiogram is not necessary.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is undergoing major vascular surgery, which is considered a high-risk procedure. She has no cardiac symptoms, but she has three major cardiac risk factors (insulin-requiring diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and ischemic heart disease) and limited functional capacity (<4 metabolic equivalents). Sending the patient to surgery without additional testing is inappropriate.

Because the patient’s heart rate is already low, increasing the beta-blocker dose is unlikely to be beneficial.

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not indicated as initial preoperative testing in an asymptomatic patient. It may be appropriate following a cardiac stress test based on the degree of ischemia identified.

Sending the patient to surgery without additional testing is inappropriate.

On physical examination, she has normal carotid pulses, clear lungs, and no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. She has a minimally radiating 2/6 early systolic murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border; the second heart sound is of normal intensity.

This patient has no evidence of unstable coronary disease and no evidence of heart failure or volume overload. She may proceed to elective knee surgery without any further cardiac testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine preoperative carotid ultrasonography is not indicated before orthopedic surgery.

Her systolic murmur is most likely related to aortic sclerosis (without stenosis), given its location, the early systolic timing, the minimal radiation, the normal intensity of the second heart sound, the normal carotid pulses, and the absence of symptoms suggesting obstructive valvular disease. D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial perfusion imaging and cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography are unnecessary, given that the patient does not report angina and has adequate functional capacity.

E) INCORRECT:

Myocardial perfusion imaging and cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography are unnecessary, given that the patient does not report angina and has adequate functional capacity.

Other studies suggest that beta-blockers may confer some benefit in high-risk patients if the drugs are initiated several weeks before surgery — with careful dose titration well before the date of surgery to avoid hypotension or bradycardia. Patients who have been taking and tolerating beta-blockers long term should continue to take them through the pre- and postoperative periods.

This patient’s peripheral arterial disease indicates that he has atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease; initiating a statin is therefore indicated either pre- or postoperatively for long-term cardiovascular risk reduction.

Key learning point: In a patient undergoing vascular surgery with no other clinical risk factors or active cardiac conditions, initiation of a beta-blocker on the morning of surgery is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Starting clopidogrel on the morning of major vascular surgery is likely to have little benefit and may increase the risk of postoperative bleeding.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is admitted on the morning of elective coronary artery bypass surgery. He has a history of polymyositis that has been well controlled with chronic prednisone. His prednisone dose has been slowly tapered over the past 4 months from 25 mg daily to 15 mg daily, which has been his dose for the past 4 weeks. The last dose was taken 24 hours ago. His other medications are atorvastatin, atenolol, aspirin, and methotrexate.
Which one of the following treatments, if any, is most appropriate to administer to this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients receiving at least 10 mg of prednisone for more than one month develop progressive atrophy of the adrenal cortex due to chronic suppression of adrenocorticotropin release from the anterior pituitary. Patients with adrenocortical atrophy are at increased risk for developing secondary adrenal insufficiency during times of high stress, such as during major surgery. To protect against adrenal insufficiency, it is appropriate to administer a protective “stress dose” of glucocorticoids.

Hydrocortisone is the glucocorticoid that is preferred in this context, as it has been widely studied, and its hemodynamic effects can be detected within 15 minutes after intravenous administration.

Key learning point: The most appropriate glucocorticoid to administer before major surgery in a patient who has been taking a high dose of glucocorticoids for more than one month is hydrocortisone.

B) INCORRECT:

Continuing the usual glucocorticoid dose, either in oral or intravenous form, may be appropriate for minor or moderate-risk surgeries, but stress doses are generally used during major surgeries such as coronary artery bypass grafting

C) INCORRECT:

Fludrocortisone is a mineralocorticoid that lacks sufficient glucocorticoid activity to cover the needs posed by surgical stress.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral medicines such as prednisone are not recommended in patients undergoing major surgery, as their absorption may be less predictable and their oral intake may be restricted.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is a medication used to promote glycogenolysis in patients who are acutely hypoglycemic. It is not indicated for patients with adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male chronic smoker with a history of type 2 diabetes, obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and hypertension presents for preoperative risk assessment before repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. He reports that he has no chest pain, shortness of breath, or other anginal symptoms at rest. He states that he can walk for a few minutes but has to stop after less than one block because of severe pain from osteoarthritis in both knees; he mainly uses a wheelchair for mobility. His current medications are lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, insulin degludec, and an ipratropium inhaler.
On examination, he has a blood pressure of 117/82 mm Hg, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, an oxygen saturation of 94% while he breathes ambient air, and a BMI of 37. He has normal jugular venous pressure and no carotid bruits. His lungs are clear to auscultation, without wheezing, and cardiac examination demonstrates a regular rate and rhythm, without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Palpation of the abdomen reveals a pulsatile mass, without evidence of enlarged liver or spleen. Lower extremities are without edema and have normal strength. Both knees have diminished range of motion.
Laboratory testing is remarkable for a serum creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), a hemoglobin concentration of 15 g/dL (13.5–17.5), and a glycated hemoglobin level of 6.9% (4.3–5.6).
An electrocardiogram documents sinus rhythm with a left bundle-branch block, which is chronic.
According to the 2014 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guideline on perioperative cardiovascular evaluation and management, further risk stratification should be considered in this case. If further evaluation is done, which one of the following tests should be performed next in this patient?

choices.text: Regadenoson stress test with myocardial perfusion study

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is unable to exercise and has a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which precludes interpretation of ischemic electrocardiographic changes. Therefore, an exercise stress test is not appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Resting echocardiography, without any form of pharmacologic stress, is inadequate in this scenario. Although resting echocardiography provides important structural information and may be indicated if valvular heart disease is suspected, it would not give adequate information regarding the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease and the cardiac response to the stress of surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine preoperative cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography prior to stratification by stress testing is not recommended, even for a high-risk patient.

D) CORRECT:

Most patients scheduled to undergo elective noncardiac surgery should be assessed for risk of a perioperative cardiovascular event to help guide and optimize therapy before surgery and to help balance the risks and benefits of the proposed procedure. According to the 2014 guideline from the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) on perioperative cardiovascular evaluation, stress testing may be reasonable for patients who meet all three of the following criteria:

• ≥1% perioperative risk for major adverse cardiac events
• Unknown or poor functional capacity (i.e., inability to perform 4 metabolic equivalents [METs])
• Anticipation that testing will “impact decision-making or perioperative care”

This patient is scheduled for high-risk surgery and has two other high-risk factors according to the Revised Cardiac Risk Index (diabetes requiring insulin therapy and serum creatinine >2 mg/dL). In addition, his functional status is unknown, given his limited ability for exertion related to knee osteoarthritis. If the clinician and patient decide that an abnormal stress test might affect decision-making — for example, by prompting further evaluation and coronary intervention before the aortic aneurysm repair — then stress testing would be reasonable.

When considering stress testing, clinicians must decide on the mode of stressing the heart and the mode of imaging. This patient is unable to exercise and has a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which precludes interpretation of ischemic electrocardiographic changes. Therefore, an exercise stress test is not appropriate, and the patient will require pharmacologic stressing coupled with imaging.

Stress testing with regadenoson (a coronary vasodilator) plus myocardial perfusion imaging is the preferred test for this patient. The myocardial perfusion imaging will allow for both rest and stress imaging that is not affected by the patient’s conduction defect or his inability to exercise. Although active bronchospasm is a contraindication to regadenoson, this patient has stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease without active bronchospasm, and regadenoson can be used in this setting.

Dobutamine stress echocardiography is another preoperative stress imaging modality that could be considered for risk assessment in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. However, it has traditionally been avoided in patients with LBBB because of concern that the dyssynchrony of the wall motion related to the conduction defect would make the echocardiographic images difficult to interpret, thus reducing the sensitivity of the test. More recently, a potential role for dobutamine stress echocardiography has been proposed even in the presence of LBBB, although this is not yet considered a standard stress testing scenario.

Of note, the ACC/AHA guideline has become the general standard of care for perioperative cardiovascular evaluation in the United States, but several of its elements are controversial. First, the 1% threshold to denote high risk is somewhat arbitrary, and different risk calculators yield different estimates. Second, estimating functional capacity according to METs to determine need for further evaluation has not been validated; one recent study found no correlation between estimated METs and perioperative myocardial infarction. Finally, although the directive for stress testing “if it will impact decision-making” gives clinicians appropriate discretion, some clinicians appear to order stress testing routinely for all patients with >1% risk and poor functional capacity.

Key learning point: If additional preoperative cardiovascular risk stratification is needed before high-risk surgery in a patient at elevated cardiovascular risk with unknown functional status, the most appropriate preoperative test to consider is a pharmacological myocardial perfusion study.

E) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine stress cardiac MRI is a new modality of stress imaging that requires specialized centers of excellence and a skilled team to perform. There are insufficient data to support the use of this modality in preoperative risk assessment.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 61-year-old man with chronic right knee pain from advanced osteoarthritis visits the clinic. After months of conservative treatment, total knee arthroplasty is recommended. He expresses skepticism about efficacy and worries about complications, stating he wants to 'wait and see.' Vital signs are stable. Physical exam shows decreased range of motion and persistent pain with movement. What is the most appropriate next step in managing his concerns?

choices.text: Postpone any further discussions until he returns requesting an operative intervention
Prescribe continued conservative management without further explanation or counseling
Arrange a dedicated consultation with the surgical team and allied health professionals to clarify his questions and discuss realistic outcomes
Emphasize that serious complications are uncommon and advise proceeding with surgery as soon as possible

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying discussions about surgery neglects the opportunity to address the patient's concerns about total knee arthroplasty. His skepticism and worries require timely communication to clarify misconceptions and provide necessary education, facilitating informed consent and aligning the management plan with his preferences.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient's chronic osteoarthritis and lack of improvement with conservative management suggest that nonoperative treatment has been exhausted. Continuing conservative management without addressing his concerns fails to engage in shared decision-making and does not provide the information needed for an informed choice.

C) CORRECT:

Effective communication in surgical decision-making involves addressing the patient's concerns directly. A dedicated consultation with the surgical team allows for a detailed discussion of total knee arthroplasty, including realistic outcomes, potential complications, and the recovery process. This approach supports shared decision-making by integrating the patient's values and preferences into the treatment plan, fostering trust, and enabling an informed decision.

Key learning point: When a patient is skeptical about surgery, it is important to address their concerns with empathy and provide comprehensive information through a multidisciplinary approach, allowing them to make an informed decision.

D) INCORRECT:

While serious complications in total knee arthroplasty are uncommon, emphasizing this without addressing the patient's concerns about efficacy and complications overlooks his need for reassurance and information. Immediate advice to proceed with surgery without engaging in shared decision-making may undermine his autonomy and trust.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy due to symptomatic gallstones. She has well-controlled hypertension and no prior abdominal operations. She has no medication allergies. Laboratory values, including white blood cell count, are normal. On the day of surgery, her vital signs are stable. The surgical team discusses measures to minimize postoperative complications.
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to reduce the likelihood of a surgical site infection in this patient?

choices.text: Delay antibiotic therapy until the surgical procedure is completed
Single intravenous dose of antibiotics within one hour before incision
Antibiotic infusion three hours prior to the anticipated incision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administering antibiotics after surgery fails to achieve therapeutic tissue levels at the time of incision, missing the critical window for preventing bacterial contamination. Guidelines recommend administering antibiotics within one hour before incision to ensure optimal systemic and tissue levels during surgery.

B) CORRECT:

Administering a single intravenous dose of antibiotics within one hour before surgical incision ensures peak tissue concentrations at the time of incision, effectively preventing initial bacterial contamination. This timing optimizes the antibiotic's pharmacokinetics, providing adequate prophylaxis during the period of highest risk for bacterial inoculation. In laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a clean or clean-contaminated procedure, this approach aligns with established guidelines, minimizing unnecessary antibiotic exposure and reducing the risk of adverse events and antibiotic resistance.

Key learning point: For surgical prophylaxis in procedures like laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a single dose of antibiotics administered within 60 minutes before incision is recommended to prevent surgical site infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Extended postoperative antibiotic use is unnecessary in low-risk, clean or clean-contaminated procedures like elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Prolonged use increases the risk of adverse effects, antibiotic resistance, and superinfections without additional benefit in reducing surgical site infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering antibiotics three hours before incision may result in declining serum and tissue levels by the time of incision, reducing prophylactic effectiveness. Guidelines recommend administration within one hour before incision to maintain effective antibiotic levels during the period of highest contamination risk.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a 12-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with metformin and a stable insulin regimen. His latest HbA1c is 6.8%. He reports near-normal exercise tolerance and denies chest pain or dyspnea. He has mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy without vision impairment. Physical examination and routine lab results are normal.
Which of the following ASA classifications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ASA IV is for patients with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life. This patient’s diabetes is well-controlled, with a near-target HbA1c and mild retinopathy. His stable condition and near-normal exercise tolerance do not meet the criteria for ASA IV.

B) INCORRECT:

ASA I is for patients who are completely healthy with no systemic disease. This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, indicating underlying systemic disease. Even with excellent control, chronic conditions like diabetes require a classification beyond ASA I.

C) CORRECT:

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System categorizes patients based on the severity of systemic disease. ASA II is appropriate for patients with mild systemic disease that does not significantly limit daily activities. This patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled with metformin and insulin, as indicated by his HbA1c of 6.8% and near-normal exercise tolerance. His mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy further supports the presence of a controlled chronic condition, aligning with ASA II criteria.

Key learning point: A patient with well-controlled diabetes is classified as ASA II, indicating mild systemic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

ASA III is for patients with severe systemic disease that significantly limits daily activity. This patient's diabetes is well-managed, with a near-normal HbA1c and stable exercise tolerance. His mild retinopathy does not indicate severe systemic compromise, making ASA III inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with a perforated peptic ulcer requiring urgent surgical intervention. He has a history of congestive heart failure, end-stage renal disease on dialysis, and severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has oliguria and altered mental status. Despite aggressive resuscitation, his clinical condition continues to decline.

Blood pressure
78/45 mm Hg

Which ASA physical status classification best describes his current state?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ASA 3 is for patients with severe systemic disease that limits activity but is not an immediate threat to life. This patient has significant comorbidities, but his acute decompensation, including a perforated peptic ulcer, persistent hypotension, oliguria, and altered mental status, indicates a life-threatening condition beyond ASA 3.

B) INCORRECT:

ASA 4 is for patients with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life. While this patient has significant comorbidities, his acute decompensation, marked by hypotension, oliguria, and altered mental status, indicates active physiological failure, exceeding the criteria for ASA 4.

C) INCORRECT:

ASA 6 is for individuals declared brain dead for organ donation. This patient, despite being critically ill, does not meet the criteria for brain death, which requires the absence of cerebral and brainstem function.

D) CORRECT:

The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification system assesses preoperative health to estimate anesthetic risk. ASA 5 is for moribund patients not expected to survive without surgery. This patient has a perforated peptic ulcer and severe comorbidities, including congestive heart failure, end-stage renal disease on dialysis, and severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His oliguria, altered mental status, and persistent hypotension despite aggressive resuscitation indicate hemodynamic instability and multi-organ involvement, fitting the criteria for ASA 5.

Key learning point: ASA Class V is assigned to patients who are moribund and not expected to survive without surgical intervention, such as those in septic shock requiring high inotropic support.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Over the past week, he has experienced increased shortness of breath when lying flat, bilateral lower extremity swelling, and a weight gain of 3 kg. Physical examination shows an S3 heart sound and bibasilar crackles. A routine preoperative echocardiogram demonstrates an ejection fraction of 35%.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Single dose of intravenous diuretic and immediate operation
Postpone the procedure to optimize cardiac status

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While the patient has risk factors for coronary artery disease, his presentation is primarily indicative of decompensated systolic heart failure, not acute coronary syndrome. There is no evidence of anginal symptoms or ischemic changes that would necessitate coronary angiography. The focus should be on optimizing heart failure management before elective surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Administering a single diuretic dose may temporarily relieve fluid overload but does not address the underlying systolic dysfunction. The patient's ejection fraction of 35% and heart failure symptoms require comprehensive optimization of cardiac status. Immediate surgery without proper stabilization poses significant perioperative risks due to compromised cardiac reserve.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including orthopnea, bilateral lower extremity edema, an S3 heart sound, and bibasilar crackles, along with an ejection fraction of 35%, indicate decompensated systolic heart failure. This condition reflects impaired ventricular contractility and volume overload, leading to hemodynamic instability. As the surgery is elective, postponing it allows for the initiation or optimization of medical therapies such as angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, beta-blockers, and diuretics. This optimization aims to improve ventricular function and reduce perioperative risks, including arrhythmias and worsening heart failure.

Key learning point: In patients with signs of heart failure, elective surgeries should be postponed until the patient's condition is optimized to reduce the risk of perioperative complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Although laparoscopic cholecystectomy is generally low-risk, the patient's decompensated heart failure, evidenced by symptoms like orthopnea and an ejection fraction of 35%, increases perioperative risk. Proceeding with surgery without stabilizing the cardiac condition can lead to complications such as arrhythmias and myocardial ischemia due to the hemodynamic stress of anesthesia and surgery.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old G2P1 woman is scheduled for an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks gestation due to persistent breech presentation. She has no known medication allergies and is fasting. Operating room staff estimate incision time in approximately 30 minutes. She has not received any antibiotics yet.
What is the most appropriate time to administer prophylactic antibiotics for this procedure?

choices.text: Only if signs of infection develop post-procedure
Within one hour before the first incision
Immediately after the neonate is delivered

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered before the incision to establish effective tissue levels at the time of bacterial contamination. Waiting for signs of infection delays intervention, allowing bacteria to seed tissues during surgery, which makes later treatment less effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Administering antibiotics postoperatively does not ensure sufficient tissue levels at the time of incision, when bacterial contamination is most likely. Prophylactic antibiotics should peak during the operation to prevent surgical site infections. Postoperative administration does not serve the purpose of preoperative prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Administering prophylactic antibiotics within one hour before the first incision ensures adequate tissue levels during the surgical procedure, reducing the risk of postoperative infections such as surgical site infections and endometritis. This timing aligns the antibiotic's peak concentration with the period of greatest bacterial exposure. Current guidelines support this approach in cesarean deliveries, optimizing maternal protection and maintaining neonatal safety by preventing intraoperative bacterial contamination.

Key learning point: Prophylactic antibiotics for cesarean sections should be administered during pre-operative preparation to ensure adequate tissue levels at the time of incision and reduce the risk of postoperative infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering antibiotics after neonatal delivery fails to provide optimal prophylaxis for the mother. The goal is to achieve adequate tissue concentrations at the time of incision to prevent bacterial colonization. Delaying until after delivery leaves the surgical site unprotected during the period of highest bacterial contamination risk.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with well-controlled, moderate persistent asthma is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Her current regimen includes a daily inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist combination inhaler and an albuterol inhaler for rescue, which she uses less than once per week. She has had no exacerbations requiring oral steroids in the past year. Her physical examination reveals clear breath sounds bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative therapeutic recommendation to reduce this patient's risk of bronchospasm?

choices.text: Withhold her daily combination inhaler on the morning of surgery.
Schedule pre-operative pulmonary function tests to confirm stability.
Administer a prophylactic dose of her albuterol inhaler shortly before anesthesia induction.
Initiate a 5-day course of oral prednisone beginning 3 days preoperatively.
Substitute her albuterol with an ipratropium inhaler for the perioperative period.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Controller medications, such as an inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist, are crucial for maintaining baseline asthma control by reducing airway inflammation and hyperreactivity. Withholding this therapy would increase the patient's risk of perioperative bronchospasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Preoperative pulmonary function tests are not routinely indicated for patients with a clear history and physical examination consistent with well-controlled asthma. PFTs are generally reserved for patients whose asthma control is uncertain, who have unexplained dyspnea or wheezing, or who are undergoing thoracic surgery. Given this patient's stable clinical status, PFTs would not change management and would unnecessarily delay surgery.

C) CORRECT:

For patients with asthma undergoing procedures involving endotracheal intubation, which is a significant trigger for bronchospasm, prophylactic treatment is recommended even if the asthma is well-controlled. Administering a short-acting beta-agonist, such as albuterol, 15 to 30 minutes before intubation provides maximal bronchodilation at the time of highest risk. This preemptive measure effectively blunts airway hyperreactivity and reduces the likelihood of intraoperative complications. The patient's controller medication (inhaled corticosteroid/long-acting beta-agonist) should also be continued through the morning of surgery to maintain baseline control of inflammation and bronchomotor tone. This combined approach is the standard of care for perioperative asthma management.

D) INCORRECT:

A perioperative course of systemic corticosteroids may be considered for patients with poorly controlled asthma or those who have had a recent exacerbation requiring steroids. This patient's asthma is well-controlled, as evidenced by infrequent rescue inhaler use and no recent exacerbations. Prophylactic oral steroids in this setting would offer no clear benefit and would introduce unnecessary risks, such as hyperglycemia and impaired wound healing.

E) INCORRECT:

While ipratropium is a bronchodilator, short-acting beta-agonists like albuterol are more potent and have a faster onset of action, making them the preferred first-line agents for prophylaxis against bronchospasm triggered by intubation. Ipratropium is more commonly used as an adjunctive agent in the management of severe asthma exacerbations, but it is not the primary choice for pre-operative prophylaxis in a stable patient.
questions.hint: Despite this patient's asthma being well-controlled at baseline, the instrumentation of the airway during anesthesia is a potent trigger for bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is scheduled for elective hernia repair, and her mother is visibly anxious. Which step best lowers her preoperative anxiety?

choices.text: Encourage the mother to avoid researching the procedure beforehand
Suggest prescribing a mild sedative for the mother
Reassure her that surgical complications are extremely rare
Provide a clear overview of the operation and recovery expectations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Limiting a parent's access to information can increase anxiety. Structured preoperative education provides clear, reliable information, addressing fears and uncertainties. Discouraging research can lead to increased uncertainty and a sense of being inadequately informed.

B) INCORRECT:

Prescribing a sedative for the mother may impair her ability to provide comfort and reassurance, which are crucial for the child. Nonpharmacologic strategies that foster communication and support are more effective in reducing anxiety.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassuring the parent about low complication rates does not directly address the emotional needs of a child facing surgery. Anxiety in young children is better reduced by interventions that address their understanding and coping mechanisms, such as familiarizing them with the environment or using age-appropriate explanations.

D) CORRECT:

Detailed preoperative education addresses parental concerns by explaining the surgical process and recovery expectations. This demystifies the procedure, allowing the parent to form realistic expectations about the timeline, postoperative care, and potential limitations. Such information reduces uncertainty and increases the parent's sense of control and preparedness, which lowers anxiety. Understanding the procedure and recovery equips the parent to support the child emotionally and practically.

Key learning point: Providing clear explanations of the surgical process and what to expect can significantly reduce anxiety in parents of children scheduled for surgery.
